column2: I resisted all the way: a new thing for me, and a circumstance which greatly strengthened the bad opinion Bessie and Miss Abbot were disposed to entertain of me.
column3: I resisted all the way: a new thing for me, and a circumstance which greatly strengthened the bad opinion Bessie and Miss Abbot were disposed to entertain of me.

column2: Master!	Master!
No; you are less than a servant, for you do nothing for your keep. There, sit down, and think over your wickedness.
column3: No; you are less than a servant, for you do nothing for your keep. There, sit down, and think over your wickedness.

column2: If you don't sit still, you must be tied down, said Bessie.
column3: If you don't sit still, you must be tied down, said Bessie.

column2: Miss Abbot turned to divest a stout leg of the necessary ligature.
column3: Miss Abbot turned to divest a stout leg of the necessary ligature.

column2: This preparation for bonds, and the additional ignominy it inferred, took a little of the excitement out of me.
column3: This preparation for bonds, and the additional ignominy it inferred, took a little of the excitement out of me.

column2: Don't take them off, I cried; "I will not stir."
column3: Don't take them off, I cried; "I will not stir."

column2: But it was always in her, was the reply.
column3: But it was always in her, was the reply.

column2: I had nothing to say to these words: they were not new to me: my very first recollections of existence included hints of the same kind.
column3: I had nothing to say to these words: they were not new to me: my very first recollections of existence included hints of the same kind.

column2: This reproach of my dependence had become a vague sing-song in my ear: very painful and crushing, but only half intelligible.
column3: This reproach of my dependence had become a vague sing song in my ear: very painful and crushing, but only half intelligible.

column2: Miss Abbot joined in--
column3: Miss Abbot joined in-

column2: They will have a great deal of money, and you will have none: it is your place to be humble, and to try to make yourself agreeable to them."
column3: They will have a great deal of money, and you will have none: it is your place to be humble, and to try to make yourself agreeable to them."

column2: Besides, said Miss Abbot, "God will punish her: He might strike her dead in the midst of her tantrums, and then where would she go?
column3: Besides, said Miss Abbot, "God will punish her: He might strike her dead in the midst of her tantrums, and then where would she go?

column2: Come, Bessie, we will leave her: I wouldn't have her heart for anything.
column3: Come, Bessie, we will leave her: I wouldn't have her heart for anything.

column2: Say your prayers, Miss Eyre, when you are by yourself; for if you don't repent, something bad might be permitted to come down the chimney and fetch you away."
column3: Say your prayers, Miss Eyre, when you are by yourself; for if you don't repent, something bad might be permitted to come down the chimney and fetch you away."

column2: They went, shutting the door, and locking it behind them.
column3: They went, shutting the door, and locking it behind them.

column2: The red-room was a square chamber, very seldom slept in, I might say never, indeed, unless when a chance influx of visitors at Gateshead Hall rendered it necessary to turn to account all the accommodation it contained: yet it was one of the largest and stateliest chambers in the mansion.
column3: The red room was a square chamber, very seldom slept in, I might say never, indeed, unless when a chance influx of visitors at Gateshead Hall rendered it necessary to turn to account all the accommodation it contained: yet it was one of the largest and stateliest chambers in the mansion.

column2: Scarcely less prominent was an ample cushioned easy-chair near the head of the bed, also white, with a footstool before it; and looking, as I thought, like a pale throne.
column3: Scarcely less prominent was an ample cushioned easy chair near the head of the bed, also white, with a footstool before it; and looking, as I thought, like a pale throne.

column2: This room was chill, because it seldom had a fire; it was silent, because remote from the nursery and kitchen; solemn, because it was known to be so seldom entered.
column3: This room was chill, because it seldom had a fire; it was silent, because remote from the nursery and kitchen; solemn, because it was known to be so seldom entered.

column2: I was not quite sure whether they had locked the door; and when I dared move, I got up and went to see.
column3: I was not quite sure whether they had locked the door; and when I dared move, I got up and went to see.

column2: Alas! yes: no jail was ever more secure.
column3: Alas! yes: no jail was ever more secure.

column2: I returned to my stool.
column3: I returned to my stool.

column2: Why was I always suffering, always browbeaten, always accused, for ever condemned?
column3: Why was I always suffering, always browbeaten, always accused, for ever condemned?

column2: Why could I never please?
column3: Why could I never please?

column2: Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage, was universally indulged.
column3: Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage, was universally indulged.

column2: Her beauty, her pink cheeks and golden curls, seemed to give delight to all who looked at her, and to purchase indemnity for every fault.
column3: Her beauty, her pink cheeks and golden curls, seemed to give delight to all who looked at her, and to purchase indemnity for every fault.

column2: What a consternation of soul was mine that dreary afternoon!
column3: What a consternation of soul was mine that dreary afternoon!

column2: Yet in what darkness, what dense ignorance, was the mental battle fought!
column3: Yet in what darkness, what dense ignorance, was the mental battle fought!

column2: I know that had I been a sanguine, brilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, romping child--though equally dependent and friendless--Mrs.
column3: I know that had I been a sanguine, brilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, romping child-though equally dependent and friendless-mrs

column2: That certainly was a crime: and was I fit to die?
column3: That certainly was a crime: and was I fit to die?

column2: Or was the vault under the chancel of Gateshead Church an inviting bourne?
column3: Or was the vault under the chancel of Gateshead Church an inviting bourne?

column2: In such vault I had been told did Mr. Reed lie buried; and led by this thought to recall his idea, I dwelt on it with gathering dread.
column3: In such vault I had been told did mr Reed lie buried; and led by this thought to recall his idea, I dwelt on it with gathering dread.

column2: It must have been most irksome to find herself bound by a hard-wrung pledge to stand in the stead of a parent to a strange child she could not love, and to see an uncongenial alien permanently intruded on her own family group.
column3: It must have been most irksome to find herself bound by a hard wrung pledge to stand in the stead of a parent to a strange child she could not love, and to see an uncongenial alien permanently intruded on her own family group.

column2: I wiped my tears and hushed my sobs, fearful lest any sign of violent grief might waken a preternatural voice to comfort me, or elicit from the gloom some haloed face, bending over me with strange pity.
column3: I wiped my tears and hushed my sobs, fearful lest any sign of violent grief might waken a preternatural voice to comfort me, or elicit from the gloom some haloed face, bending over me with strange pity.

column2: This idea, consolatory in theory, I felt would be terrible if realised: with all my might I endeavoured to stifle it--I endeavoured to be firm.
column3: This idea, consolatory in theory, I felt would be terrible if realised: with all my might I endeavoured to stifle it-I endeavoured to be firm.

column2: Shaking my hair from my eyes, I lifted my head and tried to look boldly round the dark room; at this moment a light gleamed on the wall.
column3: Shaking my hair from my eyes, I lifted my head and tried to look boldly round the dark room; at this moment a light gleamed on the wall.

column2: Was it, I asked myself, a ray from the moon penetrating some aperture in the blind?
column3: Was it, I asked myself, a ray from the moon penetrating some aperture in the blind?

column2: Miss Eyre, are you ill? said Bessie.
column3: Miss Eyre, are you ill? said Bessie.

column2: Take me out!	Take me out!
What for?	What for?
Have you seen something?" again demanded Bessie.
column3: Have you seen something?" again demanded Bessie.

column2: And what a scream!	And what a scream!
If she had been in great pain one would have excused it, but she only wanted to bring us all here: I know her naughty tricks."
column3: If she had been in great pain one would have excused it, but she only wanted to bring us all here: I know her naughty tricks."

column2: Let her go, was the only answer.
column3: Let her go, was the only answer.

column2: Loose Bessie's hand, child: you cannot succeed in getting out by these means, be assured.	Loose Bessie's hand, child: you cannot succeed in getting out by these means, be assured.

I abhor artifice, particularly in children; it is my duty to show you that tricks will not answer: you will now stay here an hour longer, and it is only on condition of perfect submission and stillness that I shall liberate you then."
column3: I abhor artifice, particularly in children; it is my duty to show you that tricks will not answer: you will now stay here an hour longer, and it is only on condition of perfect submission and stillness that I shall liberate you then."

column2: O aunt! have pity!	O aunt! have pity!
Forgive me!
column3: Forgive me!

column2: I shall be killed if--"
column3: I shall be killed if-"

column2: I was a precocious actress in her eyes; she sincerely looked on me as a compound of virulent passions, mean spirit, and dangerous duplicity.
column3: I was a precocious actress in her eyes; she sincerely looked on me as a compound of virulent passions, mean spirit, and dangerous duplicity.

column2: Bessie and Abbot having retreated, Mrs. Reed, impatient of my now frantic anguish and wild sobs, abruptly thrust me back and locked me in, without farther parley.
column3: Bessie and Abbot having retreated, mrs Reed, impatient of my now frantic anguish and wild sobs, abruptly thrust me back and locked me in, without farther parley.

column2: I heard her sweeping away; and soon after she was gone, I suppose I had a species of fit: unconsciousness closed the scene.
column3: I heard her sweeping away; and soon after she was gone, I suppose I had a species of fit: unconsciousness closed the scene.
